contracts [4][7][9]-brokers of insurance and financial products-contract for sale of goodwill in part of business based on client list-whether contract incomplete for lack of essential terms-whether nature of property in client list sufficiently clear-property is ability to produce income stream from list price must almost always be identified-insufficient identification of price or nature of property indicated arrangement was in third class of masters v cameron. corporations [105]-directors' duties-duty not to improperly use information gained as director-information must be gained because of defendant's role as director. evidence [138]-clients' status reports-original material on which reports are based must be available if presented by non-accountant-difficulties arising where material stored on computer. intellectual property [112]-confidential information-client contact list-ex "employee" used list to attract clients away from former "employer"-whether information sufficiently confidential for equity to protect in absence of express or implied contractual term-employee entitled to rely upon retained knowledge-nature of relationship between employer and employee and instructions given to employee important-question of fact-client lists generally in borderline position.

application of jones v dunkel [1959] hca 8 ; (1959) 101 clr 298 to criminal trials. gaudron and hayne jj. in 1999, the appellant was indicted, in the district court of new south wales, on a charge of indecently assaulting a 13 year old girl in 1988

11 years earlier. although the indictment alleged that the offence had occurred between specified dates, by the end of the prosecution case it was clear that it was alleged that the assault had occurred on the morning of 29 july 1988. in an unsworn statement at his trial, the appellant acknowledged that he had seen the complainant that morning, but he said that it was only in the company of her mother, and while he was otherwise engaged in meetings with others. the appellant's appointment diary was tendered in evidence. it recorded a number of appointments for the appellant during the day. no appointment with the complainant was recorded. there were, however, references to a meeting at 9.30 am with two other persons, a meeting between 1.00 pm and 3.00 pm with several other persons, including the complainant's mother, and what was described as a "processing session" with a ms tinkler between 9.30 am and 11.30 am in a room called the "energy conversion room". the complainant swore that the appellant had indecently assaulted her in that room at the end of a "processing session" with her in the morning of 29 july 1988.

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 4(2). held: (1) publication of statements, including statements of opinion, made in the ordinary course of the publication of a newspaper can constitute misleading and deceptive conduct within the trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 52. there is no definable boundary between conduct which is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive and material which is defamatory; defamatory material does not fall outside the operation of s. 52(1) merely by reason of its being defamatory.

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 52 (1). the respondents were sued as representatives of the forest products association of western australia, an association of companies engaged in the timber and woodchipping industry. the western australian forests department joined with the association and its members in paying for the production of a documentary film called "forests forever", intended to explain to the public the basis on which the forests department was managing the south west forest for various uses, and as a renewable resource for commercial purposes.

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 45d (1). the appellant, tillmanns butcheries pty. ltd. ("tillmanns"), was a wholesale and retail butcher carrying on business in canberra and queanbeyan. the first-named respondent, the australasian meat industry employees' union ("the union") was an organization of employees including employees of wholesale and retail butchers and employees in abattoirs. the third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents were the president, secretary and two organizers of the union respectively. in december 1977 two of the respondents entered tillmannss' shop in queanbeyan and asked to see the employees. the request was refused by tillmanns' managing director because it was neither smoko nor lunchtime. the union retaliated by imposing a black ban upon tillmanns' shops. at that time canberra abattoir pty. ltd. ("canberra abattoir"), a company which conducted an abattoir in the australian capital territory, held for tillmanns thirty-two cattle awaiting slaughter and the carcasses of twenty head of cattle and seventeen pigs. as a result of the black ban by the union the live cattle were not slaughtered for some weeks and the carcasses were released to tillmanns only about a week later to avoid deterioration. the appellant instituted an action in the federal court of australia seeking an injunction and damages under ss. 80 and 82 in relation to s. 45d of the trade practices act 1974 ("the act ") alleging that the respondents acted in concert to prevent supplies of meat to tillmanns in breach of s. 45d of the act . the trial judge declined to find that the respondents' conduct had the relevant effect and refused to award damages or to grant an injunction. he stated in his judgment, inter alia, that the plaintiff (appellant) was not entitled to argue that the conduct complained of would be likely to cause substantial loss where the means of proving whether in fact it did cause substantial loss were in its power. the appellant appealed to the full court of the federal court of australia against this judgment claiming that an injunction should have been ordered. held: per curiam

the appeal against the first, third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents should be upheld, the cross appeal of those respondents should be dismissed and the appellant should be granted injunctive relief against the above-named respondents because: (1) the appellant was entitled to seek relief on the ground that the relevant conduct of the respondents, if continued, would or would be likely to have the effect of causing substantial loss or damage to the appellant's business.

trade practices act 1974 (cth.), ss. 76 , 84 (2), 155 . the defendants carried on business at five hotels in the metropolitan area of adelaide selling packaged beer. the plaintiff commenced proceedings by writ of summons against the defendants claiming pecuniary penalties pursuant to s. 76 of the trade practices act 1974 , and injunctions pursuant to s. 80 of the act. the claim alleged breaches of s. 45 of the act in that the defendants had made an arrangement or arrived at an understanding which had the purpose or effect of substantially lessening competition and that they gave effect to that understanding. the essence of the arrangement or understanding as alleged was that the hotels operated by the defendants would on or about 5th december, 1977, fix the allowance offered to the public on each purchase of twelve 740

millilitre bottles of beer at two such bottles of beer. it was common ground that in respect of the defendants this amounted to a reduction in allowance for each purchase of twelve bottles from three bottles to two bottles for each such purchase.

citances.sentence: The Crown also submitted that the assessment of the value of the "information" is required to be prospective. In that respect, it relied upon the dicta of the Federal Court (Gilmour J) in ASIC v Fortescue Metals Group Limited (No 5) [2009] FCA 1586 ; (2009) 264 ALR 201 at 301, [474] . The chance of a real gain, the Crown contended, must have been in contemplation by the offender at the time that he placed the order of "$50,000 worth of shares in circumstances where he was required by law not to engage in such a transaction" .

The rule in Jones v Dunkel [47] is that the unexplained failure by a party to call a witness may in appropriate circumstances support an inference that the uncalled evidence would not have assisted the party's case. That is particularly so where it is the party which is the uncalled witness [48] . The failure to call a witness may also permit the court to draw, with greater confidence, any inference unfavourable to the party that failed to call the witness, if that uncalled witness appears to be in a position to cast light on whether the inference should be drawn [49] . These principles have been extended from instances where a witness has not been called at all to instances where a witness has been called but not questioned on particular topics. Where counsel for a party has refrained from asking a witness whom that party has called particular questions on an issue, the court will be less likely to draw inferences favourable to that party from other evidence in relation to that issue [50] . That problem did not arise here. The plaintiff's counsel did ask the plaintiff relevant questions.

296 A similar approach was taken in Rivkin Financial Services Ltd v Sofcom Ltd [2004] FCA 1538 ; (2004) 51 ACSR 486 in respect of the insider trading provisions of the Corporations Act and in Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Fortescue Metals Group Ltd (No 5) [2009] FCA 1586 ; (2009) ACSR 506 , where the court was concerned with s 674. These cases are considered below in relation to the non-disclosure case.
